headline: Who's Talking to Chris Wallace
subHeadline: Interview With Terry Bradshaw; Neil DeGrasse Tyson Talks To Chris Wallace. Aired 7-8p ET

utterances.speaker: SHERIFF MIKE BOUDREAUX, TULARE COUNTY, CALIFORNIA
utterances.sentences: However, having said that, the motive is not exactly clear at this point.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: That was Josh Campbell reporting.I'm Jim Acosta. See you back here at 8:00 Eastern right after "WHO'S TALKING TO CHRIS WALLACE?" That's up next. See you soon.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS WALLACE, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to WHO'S TALKING.My guests tonight include a football star and a man who's made actual stars his life's work. Up first, a gridiron great, legendary quarterback and broadcaster Terry Bradshaw on his current fight with cancer, his Hall of Fame career, and his prediction for next week's Super Bowl. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right now, who is going to win?TERRY BRADSHAW, CO-HOST, "FOX NFL SUNDAY": Right now. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Right now I'm going to have to go with --(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And later, astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson has spent years making science cool for kids except for that one decision that turned him into public enemy number one for school children.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: NEIL DEGRASSE TYSON, ASTROPHYSICIST
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. I have a file cabinet this deep, even from third graders. WALLACE

utterances.speaker: HUGH JACKMAN, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: Do I get a hint?

utterances.speaker: INA GARTEN, CHEF AND AUTHOR
utterances.sentences: I find cooking really hard. I find it really stressful.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Do you feel your life is in danger?

utterances.speaker: TYLER PERRY, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: And the love of my mother is what brought me here.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What was the worst investment?

utterances.speaker: MARK CUBAN, BILLIONAIRE ENTREPRENEUR
utterances.sentences: There is a long list of really bad ones.(END VIDEO CLIP) (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) WALLACE (voice-over): The Super Bowl is set. The Philadelphia Eagles versus the Kansas City Chiefs, and who better to talk about the big game than --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Terry Bradshaw. That's be me.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Terry Bradshaw has been a familiar face on Sundays for more than 50 years. Most of them as a broadcaster.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Right now we head over to Professor Bradshaw.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And before that as a four-time Super Bowl champ and Hall of Fame quarterback for the Pittsburgh Steelers.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Pittsburgh, hey, I love you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The ultimate performer on and off the field. Bradshaw is now tackling one of the biggest challenges of his life. Two different bouts with cancer.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Terry Bradshaw, welcome. It is so great to talk with you again. Thank you for doing this.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you for having me on. You know, I'm such a big fan of Chris Wallace and when I heard about this show, I told my wife, I love this guy. I just love his interviews. I like listening to him. So I hustled you.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let me just say by the end of this half --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: You didn't hustle me. So I thank you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: By the end of this hour, all of those feelings will have disappeared.Terry, let me start with your health.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: All right. WALLACEthat you had two different cancers that have been diagnosed in the last year. Bladder cancer and an aggressive form of skin cancer in your neck. Here you are. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Folks, I may not look like my old self but I feel like my old self. I'm cancer free, I'm feeling great, and over time, I'm going to be back to where I normally am.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, where you are today, we're talking to you, Terry, is in New Haven where you're getting treatment at Yale Medical Center, I say this for all your millions of fans, how are you doing?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Right. I'm doing great, Chris. I am -- have had follow-up -- well, I'm doing follow-up treatments for the bladder cancer. I have three weeks -- one day a week and then I come back in 90 days and do it again.When I first got the cancers, I was like, it didn't bother me. I felt like if I died from this stuff, I'm going to heaven and if I don't, then I get to sit here on earth and do football and be with my family and my gorgeous wife. So that's all good. I saw it as both sides. The thing that's most unsettling is waiting for the report after you do all the tests like and then you get the phone call and it says you're cancer free. So that's the most stressful time now. It's like today, another treatment and then another one next week, and then you come back 90 days and you feel like you're going to be good.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Honestly, are you saying you weren't scared when you got not one but two different diagnoses of cancer?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, I get that. Your wife, Tammy, was a radiation therapist for 10 years and she says that she was a lot more worried about all of this than she led on to you. How big a part has she been of your treatment and your recovery? BRADSHAWdoctor. She makes me follow up on all my scheduled medical stuff, and as I'm 74, so I go a little more often now than I used to. Had it not been for her, I would not have found out about the bladder cancer. Had it not been for her and the bladder cancer brought me to Yale because of her. If it had not been for her, I wouldn't have found the Merkel cell cancer in my neck. I'm very blessed to have her in my life. Someone that loves me and cares about me and watches over me, not only because she loves me, but also she knows, you know, that -- (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I've got a lot of issues but they're medical.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Listen, you may --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: You know what I mean.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You may not know this but they're playing a football game next week.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Super Bowl LVII. And I'm just wondering, when you look now at the teams that are in there, Philadelphia versus Kansas City, how does that shape up?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Well, I thought that Philadelphia would have a harder time with Cincinnati had Cincinnati got in because of their defense, but what I saw from Kansas City who had not played well defensively, had not been dominant but they had the potential to be, I saw them going up against Cincinnati and their defense was outstanding.You know, the couple of big throws that Joe Burrow had were just great plays by the wide receiver, so that's changed my opinion a little bit. They will have to play well. They still have to play their best game to beat Philadelphia. Philadelphia will run the football and run, and they will run and they will run. And they will play great defense. And their quarterback Jalen Hurts is excellent. The ball thrower. On the other hand, the last time we saw Kansas City go up against a great defense in a Super Bowl was when they lost to Tom Brady and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and they could do nothing like against that great Super Bowl -- in that Super Bowl. So I'm going to go back with Howie Long and we're going to look at the Tampa Bay game, and then look at the defense, and see what we can learn and how it applies to Kansas City. Kansas City has Patrick Mahomes, and as long as they have Patrick Mahomes, they've got a shot for sure.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I first met you when I was working at FOX and whenever FOX Sports was covering the Super Bowl, I would somehow convince my bosses that I needed to do my news show from the side of the Super Bowl. And here is one of our exchanges in Miami in 2020.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I'm 71. How already out?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: OK. I've got a better chance than you have.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Wait a minute, when you were winning all those games with Pittsburgh, you were younger than I was?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: One year it looks like.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) crazy. We're done.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Who are you picking in the game?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You guys don't tell ahead of time.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'll tell you. Who are you picking?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You're going to tell first.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I'll go 49ers. Who you going with?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Kansas City.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the dumbest pick I ever heard in my life.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Incidentally, Terry, my prediction looks a little better in the aftermath of that Super Bowl three years ago so here's my question, and I fully grant you the right that you may change your opinion as you and Howie go over tape and all of that stuff, right now --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Got it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- who is going to win?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Right now?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Right now I'm going to have to go with -- boy. My wife is here. She's a Chiefs fan, Chris. I'll pick -- I'll go with the Chiefs and Patrick Mahomes, and expect their defense. I know. This is terrible. I know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That was the most --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I'm such a wuss. I had been very good on picking games this year and I did pick the Chiefs, I did pick the Eagles. Both go to the Super Bowl. So I've got a good thing going there. But the more I study, the more stuff I gather, the more confused my brain gets. And so -- but I am married to a Chiefs fan so if the Chiefs don't win, no biggie. At least my wife is happy with me, my pick.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Terry, you're going to be a little bit slower Mark, I mean, Lamar Jackson. All right?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I'm 74 years old. Of course I'm slower.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This show has never been more awkward.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Everybody is standing right here has had a defining -- everybody here has had a defining moment.I lost a million bucks last week. The last time I lost a million bucks, I had a bad prenup. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hey, we in the same club.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I'm going to go with the Saints, may get some of my money back.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So honestly, do you guys really get along that well?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No rivalries? No fighting for air time?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: No. You kidding me? We are all proud of one another's accomplishments. As players we're proud of one another's accomplishments in television. As a matter of fact before I came over here today, I've got a text from Howie wishing me luck today. I mean, you know, that's the kind of friends that we are. We're very close, all of us. We're not selfish. We're not jealous of one another's money or success or anything like that.It just is a very unique bunch of men and as we're getting older, I'm sure FOX is hoping that we stay healthy so we can continue doing the show, which by the way has been number one for 29 years now, which is amazing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Coming up, we turn to Terry's storied playing career including his two famous plays which he barely remembers and the 50- year-old stigma that still gets under his skin.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: For younger generations, Terry Bradshaw may be that good old' boy on "FOX NFL Sunday," but for those of us around in the '70 he was a great quarterback who led his team to four Super Bowl victories. And along the way his highlight reel includes some of the most memorable plays in football history.You were the number one pick in the 1970 draft by the Pittsburgh Steelers out of Louisiana Tech and two years later, you were involved in a play that is still considered the greatest play in NFL history. Take a look. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Bradshaw trying to get away. And his pass is broken up by Tatum. Picked off. And he's over.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That is the immaculate reception as it was known for -- it will be known forever. Couple of things, you say that that was the worst pass you ever threw. Why?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: That was a lie. I didn't mean that.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: It was a -- it was a play, it was the fourth down play and I threw the ball and went down on the turf, and got hit, heard the roar of the crowd and then I got to thinking, wow. You know, that's some kind of throw right there. I knew it was a touchdown. So I'm thinking endorsements, movie deals are going to come my way. And it just -- this is a big moment, you know, for me. And so I got up and started jogging and the place is doing crazy and I'm, you know, I'm waiting for someone to say way to go TB, nice throw. Got none of that.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Nobody was saying, asking you to say, where you going after this game and you could say Disneyland? BRADSHAWreally? So now it's -- yes, it's not one of my best throws. Certainly ended up being my best throw, which is ironic and then of course, the great Franco Harris, one of my dear friends, passed away a few weeks back and so -- right before he had his number retired and the immaculate reception was being celebrated for 50 years in Pittsburgh. So while it was a great play for all these years, it was a sad moment when we -- when he finally got to enjoy that moment and then he passed away. So --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I got another memory for you and another past because in 1976 at another Super Bowl, you threw what is generally considered the greatest pass of all time. Let's take a look at that.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Here is Bradshaw, father from behind. Lynn Swan is open. Got it. Steelers touchdown.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What do you remember about that play?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I don't remember anything. I got knocked out. Another -- you're playing plays that I don't see. I was good at throwing it deep. I wasn't very good throwing it short but I was pretty good at throwing it deep.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You were good at throwing the ball. So let me ask you because the one thing these two plays have in common is you say that you were knocked down and almost knocked out in the second play. How many concussions do you think you suffered over the years?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So let me ask you, Terry, do you think football is too dangerous, especially the head traumas?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: No, no, I would have to say no. It's dangerous. Look, it is a tough sport. You better be pretty courageous and fear no evil basically. It was something we grew up with. It's something that I love. Being hurt or getting hit is all part of it and we accept it. And I think that's where we differ from maybe you, Chris, and some other people, is that we accept it and it's hard for a lot of people to accept it and I don't except CTE results. I don't accept a brain damage that we're fighting.I don't accept the fact we have so many of these players can't be diagnosed with CTE until it's too late. I don't think it's too rough. I played it. So obviously, I don't think it's too rough. I loved it. I enjoyed it. I was proud of myself, Chris, as a player, as a quarterback, as most quarterbacks I would think are. We have to stand in there and trust a bunch of people around us or else we just -- we just get slammed and they still get that today but the NFL has done I think a really good job of promoting taking the head out of the equation. You can't hit with the head. Protecting the quarterback. And so the improvement in the helmet is certainly better. But you're always going to be dealing with this and Chris, if we lived 20 more years, you and I would do another interview, you're going to ask me that same question again and I'm going to give you the same answer. No, I'm kind of a gladiator. I enjoyed being in that arena. That's a scary arena to be in.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I love that and I look forward to an interview in 20 years. That's a date. You had to deal, Terry, with another issue when you were playing and this was the wrap that you were, forgive me, dumb, and Hollywood Henderson famously said, you know, he couldn't spell cat if he was spotted a C and an A. Did that talk get to you? Did it get under your skin?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Yes, oh, yes, absolutely. The dumb image I have yet to figure out. A lot of interceptions my rookie year but my rookie interception record initially was broken by Peyton Manning, considered one of the smartest quarterbacks. I threw 25, he threw 28. So I've -- I am upset. I do get upset by the dumb image. I don't like it being brought up, and I think probably some of my anger and frustration with it is I didn't get enough support.I didn't feel like, personally, I didn't get enough support from Pittsburgh. I thought Chuck Noll could have stepped in and said that's the most ridiculous thing I've heard of. After all, I called my own plays. Can't be too stupid in calling your own plays.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, Chuck Noll, we should tell people who aren't as old as you and me that he was your coach at the Pittsburgh Steelers.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Right, head coach in Pittsburgh. But I have taken that image and had some fun with it. You know, I'm kind of -- as you will know, Chris, I'm -- I like to have fun in interviews, I like to entertain people. If it's at my expense, I'm fine with it. But there are times, there are times even at FOX when it's Terry's always, you know, the goofball, and there are times where I'm, I don't say anything but I do say to myself, enough, you know, enough.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right. That's enough of that.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Hey, it's -- hey, look, Chris, it's the bed that's made and I made it and I lie in it and I'm fine with it. We move on. But being honest with you, does it bother me? Yes. WALLACEof football including the decision that led to this hilarious phone call with his mother. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: After hanging up his shoulder pads, Terry Bradshaw made a career out of smart and funny analysis on Sunday afternoon but he's also dabbled in some acting and a little singing.You had quite a career outside of football and I want to talk about that a little bit. You say that music was your first love and in 1976 you recorded a song that actually made the billboard chart.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Take a look at this.(MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Did you think that you might have a career as a singer?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well? Come on. As it turns out, Super Bowl is stronger than recording. I want to ask you about acting as well, because you did some of that, including this memorable scene from "Failure to Launch."

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy.(BEGIN "FAILURE TO LAUNCH" VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: AL, FICTIONAL CHARACTER
utterances.sentences: Hey, Tripp, what are you doing here?

utterances.speaker: TRIPP, FICTIONAL CHARACTER
utterances.sentences: I just came by to get some stuff. What are you doing?

utterances.speaker: AL
utterances.sentences: Feeding the fish.

utterances.speaker: TRIPP
utterances.sentences: Yes. I see that. You're naked in my room.

utterances.speaker: AL
utterances.sentences: What? This is my naked room. It is my house.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Hey, would you have done that?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No. But you could pull it off? So here's the question because you had said --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That acting is tougher than football. Any qualms about doing that scene?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I did that naked scene just to get a rise out of America, just to go have them go "Oh my God," I swear I did that because I said this is going to be so much fun.I just didn't give it into account that I go to church every Sunday, and I didn't realize that when that movie came out on Friday, the preacher preached about the sins I had committed and how I was a bad example for young people and I left that church that morning after been there for so many years, never went back, never went back. I just couldn't believe he did that. Then I had to call my mother, Chris. She said, baby, the church is going to go to see the movie after church today. Brother Rod has got the Church bus, and we're going. We've got a box cardboard -- a box of food, and we're going to go see "Failure to Launch." I went, no. You can't go. And she says, well, why not? I said I'm naked. No, you're not. Yes, I am. I'm naked in the movie. No, you're not. Yes, I am. You wouldn't do that to your sweet old mother. Yes, I would. Oh my God. I have enjoyed that scene so much over the years. I mean, so much. I can't tell you that was one of the greatest moments of my life was doing that scene with Matthew McConaughey. And being naked, I had no problem doing it. You see from the backside, it's almost a melodrama, had they filmed me from the front side, then it would have been a comedy.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You know, you have this image and your beloved as a good old boy. But you're more complicated than that. You say that you suffered from depression and anxiety for years. You say that you wanted your football career to hurry up and be over with so that you could get off the stage.You say when you won Super Bowls, it was miserable because you felt more pressure to do it again.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What was going on there?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: And I couldn't understand people being so cruel and mean with their words, and I didn't enjoy that at all. That's why I like my life better outside of football because I get to entertain and make people laugh and have a good time, and that's the way I choose to live my life.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So let's end where we started looking -- what is the state of Terry Bradshaw today, both mentally and physically? How are you doing?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: So mentally, personally, I'm extremely happy. I feel very fortunate about that. My health, as we're -- as you and I are talking now, Chris, it my health is good. So sometimes life is just too good, and we kind of like do this. Okay, all right, where's the vials? Kind of looking over our shoulder, but I'm a blessed man.And I'm even more blessed Chris because you let me do this interview. Thank you for letting me hustle you to have me on. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Up next, from the pigskin to the planet as we tackle some cosmic question with world-class astrophysicist, Neil deGrasse Tyson. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What about aliens? And what about UFOs?

utterances.speaker: NEIL DEGRASSE TYSON, ASTROPHYSICIST
utterances.sentences: You mean aliens like with antennas and ray guns?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, something more than a set?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Okay.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Look, this voyage, we are bound for a distant galaxy.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: He has taken his love of the stars to a mass audience and given people a front row seat to some of the universe's biggest events.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: That first day began with the Big Bang.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Neil deGrasse Tyson's exploration of the cosmos.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Where did we come from? How did we get here?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Has turned him into one of the most recognizable scientists today.(CLIP FROM "THE SIMPSONS.")

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Neil deGrasse Tyson, astrophysicist.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Now, he is applying the lessons he learned observing outer space to help bridge the differences that divide us, here on Earth.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: The cosmos is yours. Come with me.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Neil deGrasse Tyson, welcome. I'm delighted to get the chance to talk to you and I am -- this is a happy coincidence, I was going to wear that exact tie.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: No, you were not. You are lying.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I promise you, I do not have a tie like that in my closet.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: I've got about 110 ties, each one is sort of uniquely capturing some aspect of the universe as imagined, or rather, as felt through the eyes of an artist.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I want to start with your latest book, "Starry MessengerIn your book, you use the device of say...

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: ... if they came here to Earth from outer space...

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: ... and they saw our wars, our politics, as you say, our inability to distinguish fact from opinion. So what do you think, said alien would say?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: So the alien comes upon Earth, beautiful blue marble, orbiting the sun, and there's oceans and land and clouds. And then they learn that there's a species that has spread itself across all the land, and so that is a very productive, very successful species.And then they come down and they say, oh, wait a minute, that same species has drawn lines on this otherwise contiguous set of landmasses. And these lines, you can't cross them unless you have special papers. Not only that, they've divided themselves by who they worship, what their skin color is, what their -- how they dress, where resources are, and where they're not on a level where they will even commit violence, even all-out war.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But we do have real differences. We do have serious differences between nations, between political parties. Are we just supposed to say from a cosmic perspective, they don't matter?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: No, no. In fact, the differences enrich the plurality of a nation, especially for a free nation. So no, I don't want to get rid of differences. I want to get rid of differences, that at their fundamental level are not different. You think they're different because you've dug your heels into some opinion, that is malformed based on what you think is true.That's different from us agreeing what is objectively true, and then sitting down and saying, oh, what do you think about this? And then you share your point of view with me, as do I? And he said, well, that's interesting. I hadn't thought about it that way. Oh, let's -- is there a way we can resolve this?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You have carved out a unique place for yourself in our intellectual life these days, and I think -- I don't know if you're going to object to this. I would describe it as the pop scientist.Here you are on one of your many shows, "Cosmos: Possible Worlds." Take a look. (BEGIN "COSMOS: POSSIBLE WORLDS" VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How did you decide on this role? And do you get pushback from -- and I say this advisedly, serious scientists.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: That pop scientists role had already been carved by Carl Sagan. And whatever sort of blood on the tracks that left, I remembered hearing about this, that he was chastised by some of his colleagues for appearing on "The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson."And this is a show that had huge reach into the taxpaying public, so at some level, we have a duty, if not an obligation to bring some of that back to the public. And yes, when I'm writing a book, I'm not doing the research paper, right? So there is a tradeoff often in that. But no, I still have strong tap roots into the research community.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You were involved in the effort to demote Pluto, you even appeared on my favorite science show, "Big Bang Theory."

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Here it is.(BEGIN "BIG BANG THEORY" VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SHELDON COOPER, FICTIONAL CHARACTER
utterances.sentences: I'm quite familiar with Dr. Tyson. He is responsible for the demotion of Pluto from planetary status. I liked Pluto. Ergo, I do not like you.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: But I actually didn't demote Pluto. That was a vote of the International Astronomical Union.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: If ifs and buts were candy and nuts, we'd all have a Merry Christmas.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is it true --

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: What? For the evidence, I can't act really, but --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, I think you did very well there.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: I did okay there? Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is it true that you got a hate mail for dissing Pluto?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. I have a file cabinet this deep. Hate mail from third graders -- third graders. WALLACE

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, so deal with it. I am just saying.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, in a minute.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why is Pluto not a planet?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, Pluto's orbit is tipped, significantly tipped out of the plane of orbits of the other planets. By the way, you know what else has tipped orbits? Comets. Okay.More than half of Pluto's volume is comprised of ice. If you brought Pluto to where Earth is now, heat from the sun would evaporate that ice and it would grow a tail. That's no kind of behavior for a planet.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Do you believe that there is life out there somewhere?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: I would say that if there weren't life, it would be astonishing. If there were -- if given how common our ingredients are and how quickly life took place here and how many planets we know are orbiting host stars. It would be astonishing if that were the case.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And what about aliens? And what about UFOs?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Well, to me any life is alien. You mean aliens, like with antennas and ray guns?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, something more than a set?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Okay. Something that could land here in a spaceship? It could be out there. There is no evidence that would convince an authentic skeptic that we've been visited. And I can tell you this, these fuzzy monochromatic Tic Tac that show up around the Navy, restricted airspace, in our own atmosphere, by the way, you've seen the high resolution images from a telescope we parked a million miles from Earth called the James Webb Space Telescope looking at the edge of the universe and the best you have of visiting aliens in our own atmosphere is a fuzzy Tic Tac? You've got to do better than that if you're going to convince an astrophysicist.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Your story begins when you're nine years old, and like every school kid in New York City, including me, you go to the Hayden Planetarium, but the difference is it changed your life. Why?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, so sometimes I wonder had I grown up on a farm somewhere, whether I wouldn't have been as starstruck as I was? Because there I am, a kid having grown up in the Bronx.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right. TYSONI know how many stars in the night sky, there are six visible from the Bronx. That was the night sky. No one in New York City has any kind of relationship with the night sky.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's true. When you go out into the real world, it is like, where do all those lights come from?

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: What are all those lights? So there, they dim the lights, and I'm struck by it. Whereas had I seen that every night of my life, this will just be, of course, this is just the night sky. So it just -- it hit me so. I don't think I chose the universe, I think the universe chose me.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: I will invert that and say, how important is it for White people to see me where I am? That's a way more important force operating, especially if that is the community that wields resources and opportunities. And if you see a Black homeless person in the street, and you never saw a Black academically achieved other human being, you're prone to say, oh, that's just their lot in life.But now, you'll see me and you'll see the Black homeless person, and you have to like deal with that. It's like, oh, my gosh, there, but for the lack of opportunity goes --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: A lot of people.

utterances.speaker: TYSON
utterances.sentences: A lot of people. So I just want to put that up front. It was a path of most resistance. Because, yes, I was also physically fit and athletic, and you see a Black person who is that particularly in the day, you should be an athlete, and that just simply fulfills people's bean that they would put you because they've never seen your kind do anything else.And my father, who was active with the Civil Rights Movement, and a sociologist, he had way worse life encounters than I did dealing with society, and he was never bitter. He said, these people don't know better. And so I've carried that with me ever since. I've never been bitter. It just is and I'll deal with it. It has forced to have me achieve that much more, to the extent that that ever becomes visible and will matter to anyone. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Tonight, the world's top musical talent is gathering in Los Angeles for the Grammy Award. We've been lucky enough to talk with several Grammy winners on this show, including Shania Twain, Dionne Warwick, Gloria Estefan and Meghan Trainor, who have won a combined 14 Grammys.In our conversations, they share their secrets for creating a Grammy- winning hit. (CLIP FROM "MAN, I FEEL LIKE A WOMAN.") (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Just the song with the words and your sound and the guitar look, did you think to yourself, this is just going to be enormous?SHANIA TWAIN, FIVE-TIME GRAMMY WINNER: I mean, I tried to get into the head of my personal fan self.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TWAIN
utterances.sentences: What do I want to listen to? What would I want to dance around the house singing?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TWAIN
utterances.sentences: But when you're first writing the song, there's no beat, there is no music, there's no production. It's just about the story and the lyric. And the hook, lyric, "Man. I feel like a woman" was very, very satisfying as a statement.(CLIP FROM "RHYTHM IS GONNA GET YOU.")

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is it true that the original name of that song was "Boogeyman's Gonna Get You?"GLORIA ESTEFAN, THREE-TIME GRAMMY WINNER: Absolutely. A drummer had come to me with the idea of the hook, because then I co-wrote it with him because I go I have a small child. I am not singing the "Boogeyman is Gonna Get You." This is insane. And I kept thinking what can we do that's not the boogeyman? And I thought what our music does, the rhythm is going to get you because wherever we went, whatever language they spoke, they were able to appreciate the rhythm and I changed it, thank the Lord. (CLIP FROM "I'M ALL ABOUT THE BASS.")

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You had the phrase "all about that bass," did you have a melody? Or did that just come to you in the chorus?MEGHAN TRAINOR, GRAMMY WINNER, 2016 BEST NEW ARTIST: We talked about I think, how are you like, we like to do out music and we liked old school. And he played the tacky, upright bass sound on a keyboard. It was just like doom, doom, doom, doom, doom, and he started making like, record beats with it. It was very impressive. And I was like, by the way I can rap and he was like, what? And I was like, I can rap. So the first verse should be like, "It's pretty clear. I ain't no size two," and we were just like, giggling. We were like, this is so funny and no one will ever sing this. (CLIP FROM "PROMISES, PROMISES.")

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Black rock songs are not easy to sing are they?DIONE WARWICK, FIVE-TIME GRAMMY WINNER: No, they're not. It was almost as if you were singing he is writing this ahead, because it's Dione who will sing this. See if she can do this.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I am going to put it through her pace.

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, give me an example. I'm going to ask you to sing, give me an example of a tempo change or something that shows how hard it was.

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: Promises, Promises now, I don't know how I got the word to walk out --You see how the tempo changed?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: That's what he does.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It is safe to say, I won't be winning a Grammy anytime soon, but I couldn't pass up the chance to sing one of my guilty pleasure songs with Shania.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TWAIN
utterances.sentences: Uh-oh-oh. Totally crazy. Forget I'm a lady. Your man shirt, short skirts.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I like that part. TWAIN

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I feel like a woman. Bump-bump, ba-dam.

utterances.speaker: TWAIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, you got the guitar part, too.(END VIDEO CLIP)
